Bill Would Block Republicans From Adopting Children
 
 http://www.365gay.com/Newscon06/02/022406gopAdopt.htm
 (Akron, Ohio) An Ohio Democrat is proposing legislation that would prevent Republicans from adopting children, a move aimed at embarrassing the GOP over moves to block gay adoptions.
 
 State Sen. Robert Hagan (D-Youngstown) admits his bill is purely "tongue-in-cheek" but says that the message is anything but a joke.

But you must realize that you have no credibility, so don't bother just asking me to "believe you".  Well, let's put this matter to rest: if you think credibility with you in particular matters one bit to me, you are sadly mistaken. Credibility isn't something to be worried with when the one trying to hold you accountable for credibility isn't credible or legit in the first place. It's kind of like scientists worrying about credibility with a flat-earth society; they just don't. A flat-earth society can call them non-credible all day long and they could care less. No, you aren't a flat-earth scientist, but it's not like you post with staightforward debate here--instead opting to quibble or chase red herrings nearly every single time you enter into a disagreeing debate rather than have to give a single inch or admit you could possibly be wrong on anything. (I suspect, at this point, you don't realize you do it.) I dont' think I've ever seen you concede a point even with anyone. And it's glaringly obvious. Frankly, it's sorta comical, which is why taking you seriously is so hard (particularly when discussing "credibility").
 
 As far as the issue of the thread, obviously the bill is tongue-in-cheek, though a waste of resources. But I've seen enough of the gay rights movement to know that many of you would love to see a bill like this come to reality, which is what I suspect of Bob as well. He's welcome to disagree if he wants, 'cause I'd prefer to be wrong on this, frankly. But when he is part of a movement that wastes no opportunity vilifying Republicans at large, and often evangelical Christians, without being willing to criticize his own movement for those generalities, I see no other conclusion to come to than outright hostility on his part. Your movement is mean, to put it as simply as I know how.
